You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

- Each reasoning should be specific to the context around the [ref] marker
- Explain the connection between the predicted titles and the research topic

- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)
- Consider retrieved papers when available to improve prediction accuracy

Paper Title: New Lower Bound and Algorithms for Online Geometric Hitting Set Problem

Paper Section Text:
The hitting set problem is one of the most fundamental problems in combinatorial optimization.
Let Σ=(𝒫,𝒮)Σ𝒫𝒮\Sigma=({\mathcal{P}},\cal S) be a range space, where 𝒫𝒫\cal P is a set of elements and 𝒮𝒮\cal S is a collection of subsets of 𝒫𝒫{\mathcal{P}} known as ranges. A subset ℋ⊆𝒫ℋ𝒫\cal H\subseteq\cal P is called a hitting set of the range space Σ=(𝒫,𝒮)Σ𝒫𝒮\Sigma=({\mathcal{P}},\cal S) if the set ℋℋ\cal H intersects every range s𝑠s in 𝒮𝒮\cal S.
The objective of the hitting set problem is to find a hitting set with the minimum cardinality.
This problem is one of Karp’s 21 classic NP-hard problems , and the best approximation factor achievable in polynomial time is Θ​(log⁡|𝒫|)Θ𝒫\Theta(\log|{\mathcal{P}}|) assuming P≠NPPNP\text{P}\neq\text{NP}  . Due to several applications in VLSI design, database management, resource allocation, facility location and wireless networks, researchers have considered the hitting set problem in geometric setup (also known as geometric hitting set problem), where the set 𝒫𝒫\cal P is a collection of points from ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}, and the set 𝒮𝒮\cal S is a finite family of geometric objects chosen from some infinite class (hypercubes, balls, etc.) [ref]1   .
By a slight misuse of the notation, we will use 𝒮𝒮\cal S to signify both the set of ranges as well as the set of objects that define these ranges.
The hitting set problem remains NP-hard, even for simple objects like unit disks and unit squares . A PTAS is known when the geometric objects are half-spaces in ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3}, and when objects are r𝑟r-admissible regions in a plane (this includes pseudo-disks) . Alon et al.  initiated the study of the online hitting set problem in a setup where the whole range space Σ=(𝒫,𝒮)Σ𝒫𝒮\Sigma=({\mathcal{P}},{\cal S}) is known in advance, but the order of arrival of the elements of 𝒮𝒮{\cal S} is not known a priori. In this setup, they proposed a deterministic O​(log⁡|𝒫|​log⁡|𝒮|)𝑂𝒫𝒮O(\log|{\mathcal{P}}|\log|\cal S|) competitive algorithm and obtained a lower bound of Ω​(log⁡|𝒫|​log⁡|𝒮|log⁡log⁡|𝒫|+log⁡log⁡|𝒮|)Ω𝒫𝒮𝒫𝒮\Omega\left(\frac{\log|{\mathcal{P}}|\log|\cal S|}{\log\log|{\mathcal{P}}|+\log\log|\cal S|}\right).
In the same setup, Even and Smorodinsky  studied the problem for various geometric range spaces and achieved an optimal competitive ratio of Θ​(log⁡|𝒫|)Θ𝒫\Theta(\log|{\mathcal{P}}|) when objects are intervals, half-planes, and unit disks, and the set 𝒫𝒫{\mathcal{P}} is a finite subset of points in ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2}. In this paper, we ask whether it is possible to obtain a similar result if we don’t know the set 𝒮𝒮\cal S in advance, and we answer affirmatively when 𝒮𝒮\cal S is similarly sized homothetic copies of any regular k𝑘k-gon. Motivated by various applications, De and Singh  considered the online hitting set problem, where 𝒫=ℤd𝒫superscriptℤ𝑑{\cal P}={\mathbb{Z}}^{d} and 𝒮𝒮\cal S consists of unit balls or hypercubes in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. For unit hypercubes, they proved that every deterministic algorithm has a competitive ratio of at least d+1𝑑1d+1; whereas they propose a randomized algorithm achieving a competitive ratio of O​(d2)𝑂superscript𝑑2O(d^{2}) for d≥3𝑑3d\geq 3. For unit balls in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}, they proposed a deterministic algorithm having a competitive ratio of O​(d4)𝑂superscript𝑑4O(d^{4}). Khan et al.  studied the problem, where, for a given M∈ℝ+𝑀superscriptℝM\in\mathbb{R}^{+}, 𝒫𝒫{\mathcal{P}} is a finite subset of [0,M)2∩ℤ2superscript0𝑀2superscriptℤ2[0,M)^{2}\cap\mathbb{Z}^{2} and the set 𝒮𝒮\cal S consists of axis-aligned integer squares s⊆[0,M)2𝑠superscript0𝑀2s\subseteq[0,M)^{2} in ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2}. Here, an integer square is a square whose all corners have integral coordinates. They obtained an O​(log⁡M)𝑂𝑀O(\log M) competitive algorithm for this variant. This result is tight since the lower bound is Ω​(log⁡M)Ω𝑀\Omega(\log M) which even holds for intervals .
